verses.text: After this, there was a feast of the Jews, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: John often records Jesus attending the Jewish feasts in Jerusalem, highlighting His fulfillment of the Law and the significance of these events in His ministry.

verses.text: Now there is in Jerusalem, by the Sheep Gate, a pool called in Hebrew Bethesda, having five covered porches.
verses.comment: Bethesda means 'House of Mercy.' The proximity to the Sheep Gate connects the pool to sacrificial imagery, pointing to Christ as the true Lamb.

verses.text: In these lay a multitude of those who were sick, blind, lame, and paralyzed, waiting for the moving of the water.
verses.comment: The gathering of the suffering here recalls messianic expectations from Isaiah where the Messiah will heal the infirm.

verses.text: [For an angel would go down at certain times into the pool and stir up the water; whoever first stepped in after the stirring of the water was made well of whatever disease he had.]
verses.comment: This verse is missing in some early manuscripts; it was likely added as an explanation for the tradition about the pool. It shows the people's belief in an angelic intervention (see also Ruth 2:13 regarding angelic visitation).

verses.text: One man was there who had been an invalid for thirty-eight years.
verses.comment: Thirty-eight years recalls the time of Israel's wandering in the wilderness, emphasizing helplessness apart from God's intervention.

verses.text: When Jesus saw him lying there and knew that he had already been in that condition a long time, he said to him, 'Do you want to be made well?'
verses.comment: Jesus' question points to the need for personal desire and consent in healing, signifying a deeper spiritual readiness.

verses.text: The sick man answered him, 'Sir, I have no one to put me into the pool when the water is stirred, but while I am coming, another steps down ahead of me.'
verses.comment: The man's answer highlights his isolation and inability to help himself, a picture of our need for a divine mediator. Compare Job 9:33.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Get up, take your mat, and walk.'
verses.comment: By His word alone, Jesus heals, demonstrating His divine authority. This anticipates the new creation brought by Christ (see Genesis 1:3).

verses.text: Immediately the man was made well, took up his mat, and began to walk. Now that day was the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Jesus heals on the Sabbath, signifying the deeper rest and healing He brings, fulfilling the Law’s intent.

verses.text: So the Jews said to the man who had been healed, 'It is the Sabbath. It is not lawful for you to carry your mat.'
verses.comment: Religious leaders focus on external observance, missing the sign of God’s mercy in Jesus’ healing.

verses.text: He answered them, 'The man who made me well said to me, “Take up your mat and walk.”'
verses.comment: He points to Jesus’ authority as the reason for his action, signifying obedience to Christ over human tradition.

verses.text: They asked him, 'Who is the man who said to you, “Take up your mat and walk”?'
verses.comment: The leaders are more concerned with the breach of Sabbath custom than the miracle itself, showing spiritual blindness (Isaiah 42:20).

verses.text: But the man who was healed did not know who it was, for Jesus had withdrawn, since there was a crowd in that place.
verses.comment: Jesus often avoids drawing too much public attention, preferring the revelation of His identity at the right time.

verses.text: Afterward Jesus found him in the temple and said to him, 'See, you have been made well. Sin no more, so that nothing worse may happen to you.'
verses.comment: Jesus connects physical healing to spiritual transformation and the forgiveness of sins. Transformation should follow divine mercy.

verses.text: The man went away and told the Jews that it was Jesus who had made him well.
verses.comment: This act reveals Jesus to the authorities, escalating the conflict regarding His authority.

verses.text: And this was why the Jews began persecuting Jesus, because he was doing these things on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Jesus’ actions challenge traditional Sabbath interpretations, revealing Himself as Lord of the Sabbath (Matt. 12:8).

verses.text: But Jesus answered them, 'My Father is working until now, and I am working.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims a unique relationship with God as His Father and puts His work—miraculous and merciful—on par with God’s own, a clear sign of His divinity.

verses.text: So because of this the Jews were seeking all the more to kill him, because he not only broke the Sabbath, but also was calling God his own Father, making himself equal with God.
verses.comment: The leaders understand Jesus’ statement as blasphemy, a claim to equality with God. This is a direct and explicit claim to divinity.

verses.text: So Jesus replied and said to them, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, the Son can do nothing by himself, but only what he sees the Father doing. For whatever the Father does, the Son does likewise.'
verses.comment: Here is the unity of will and action between the Father and the Son—showing both submission and equality, important in understanding the doctrine of the Trinity.

verses.text: For the Father loves the Son and shows him all that he himself is doing. And he will show him even greater works than these, so that you may marvel.
verses.comment: The intimate shared knowledge between Father and Son is a theme of high Christology. It prefigures the even greater works shown later: resurrection and judgment.

verses.text: For just as the Father raises the dead and gives them life, so also the Son gives life to whom he will.
verses.comment: The prerogative to give life belongs to God alone; here Jesus shares in that power, another strong claim to divinity.

verses.text: For the Father judges no one, but has given all judgment to the Son,
verses.comment: Authority to judge the world is entrusted to Jesus, emphasizing His role at the Last Judgment. Compare with Matthew 25:31-46.

verses.text: so that all may honor the Son just as they honor the Father. Whoever does not honor the Son does not honor the Father who sent him.
verses.comment: Worship and honor due God are now rendered to Jesus; a statement only appropriate if He is divine.

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, whoever hears my word and believes him who sent me has eternal life. He does not come into judgment, but has passed from death to life.
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus brings immediate participation in eternal life. Salvation involves both hearing and believing.

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, an hour is coming, and now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God, and those who hear will live.
verses.comment: The power of Jesus’ word brings spiritual life even now, not just in the future resurrection.

verses.text: For as the Father has life in himself, so he has granted the Son also to have life in himself.
verses.comment: Jesus possesses life intrinsically, just as the Father does. A high assertion of His divine nature.

verses.text: And he has given him authority to execute judgment, because he is the Son of Man.
verses.comment: The title 'Son of Man' links Jesus to Daniel’s prophetic vision of the one with authority to judge all nations.

verses.text: Do not marvel at this, for an hour is coming when all who are in the tombs will hear his voice
verses.comment: Jesus predicts the final resurrection at the last day. Both righteous and wicked will rise at His command.

verses.text: and come out—those who have done good to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil to the resurrection of judgment.
verses.comment: Works play a role in the outcome of judgment, in harmony with the teaching that faith is lived out in obedience (James 2:24).

verses.text: I can do nothing on my own. As I hear, I judge, and my judgment is just, because I seek not my own will, but the will of him who sent me.
verses.comment: Jesus remains the model of perfect obedience, showing the mystery of divine will shared in perfect unity within God.

verses.text: If I bear witness about myself, my testimony is not true.
verses.comment: Following legal requirements, Jesus emphasizes the necessity of multiple witnesses to confirm His claims.

verses.text: There is another who bears witness about me, and I know that the testimony which he gives about me is true.
verses.comment: God the Father and the works of Jesus both serve as witnesses verifying His identity.

verses.text: You have sent to John, and he has borne witness to the truth.
verses.comment: John the Baptist is identified as a human witness, sent to prepare the way for the Messiah.

verses.text: Yet I do not receive testimony from a man, but I say these things so that you may be saved.
verses.comment: Divine truth stands above human testimony; God uses witnesses for our benefit.

verses.text: He was a burning and shining lamp, and you were willing to rejoice for a while in his light.
verses.comment: John is honored, but Jesus is true Light. John's role is temporary and preparatory (Matt. 11:11).

verses.text: But the testimony that I have is greater than that of John. For the works that the Father has given me to accomplish—the very works that I am doing—bear witness about me that the Father has sent me.
verses.comment: Jesus' miracles are God’s own attestation of His unique sending and authority.

verses.text: And the Father who sent me has himself borne witness about me. You have neither heard his voice at any time nor seen his form.
verses.comment: A reference to Jesus’ baptism and Transfiguration where the Father testifies directly. Only in Jesus is God made visible.

verses.text: And you do not have his word abiding in you, because you do not believe in the one whom he has sent.
verses.comment: Lack of belief in Jesus is evidence that the Word is not internalized; relates to the idea of the Word both written and incarnate.

verses.text: You search the Scriptures, because you think that in them you have eternal life; and these are they that bear witness about me.
verses.comment: The Scriptures point to Jesus as their fulfillment. This verse encourages a Christ-centered reading of all of Scripture.

verses.text: Yet you refuse to come to me, that you may have life.
verses.comment: Knowledge of Scripture alone cannot save; true life comes from encountering and accepting Christ.

verses.text: I do not receive glory from men.
verses.comment: Jesus seeks only the approval of the Father, setting a model for humility and proper direction of worship.

verses.text: But I know that you do not have the love of God within you.
verses.comment: A severe spiritual diagnosis: lacking love of God, even while being religiously active.

verses.text: I have come in my Father’s name, and you do not receive me. If another comes in his own name, you will receive him.
verses.comment: A reference to the tendency to accept false messiahs while rejecting the true One sent by God.

verses.text: How can you believe, when you receive glory from one another and do not seek the glory that comes from the only God?
verses.comment: Worldly honor can blind us to God’s truth. The single-hearted pursuit of God’s glory is necessary for genuine faith.

verses.text: Do not think that I will accuse you to the Father; there is one who accuses you—Moses, on whom you have set your hope.
verses.comment: Jesus points to Moses as the ultimate accuser, highlighting the failure to see how the Law points to Him. Salvation comes through fulfillment of the Law in Christ.

verses.text: For if you believed Moses, you would believe me; for he wrote about me.
verses.comment: Jesus is the promised Prophet like Moses—the ultimate fulfillment of the Law and Prophets.

verses.text: But if you do not believe his writings, how will you believe my words?'
verses.comment: Rejection of God’s earlier revelation in Moses leads to rejection of Christ Himself.
